newsitem.title: USA: Ballot questions and bond referendums by state.
newsitem.headline: Ballot questions and bond referendums by state.

text.p: ALABAMA
NOVEMBER 5
--Amendment No 4 - To allow for-profit bingo in Morgan County.
--Amendment No 5 - In Jefferson County, to provide that the monetary amount of prizes for playing of bingo shall be established by local law.
--$60 million of Mobile County, Ala., special tax bonds for bridges and drainage.
ALASKA
NOVEMBER 5
--Ballot Measure No 1 to require popular approval or 2/3 vote of legislature to change Statehood Act.
ARIZONA
NOVEMBER 5

--Proposition 101 - A property tax exemption for the first $50,000 of the value of personal property that is used for agriculture, trades and business. Would allow the legislature to increase the exempt amount on a national inflation index.
--Proposition 201 - Would provide that Arizona can enter into gaming compacts with Indian Tribes that request a compact and that have not previously entered into a compact.
--Proposition 203 - Allocate $17 million of lottery revenues annually to fund six specified health and nutrition programs.
--Proposition 300 - Raise annual salaries of state legislators to $24,000 from $15,000.
ARKANSAS
NOVEMBER 5
--Amendment 1 - Establish uniform property tax rate for maintenance and operation of schools.

--Amendment 2 - Establish a sales/use tax of 1/8 of one percent to support the Arkansas Game and Fish Commission, the Department of Parks and Tourism, the Arkansas Department of Heritage and Keep Arkansas Beautiful.

--Amendment 4 - Establish state lottery, bingo games and raffles by non-profit organizations and allow voters in Hot Springs to decide whether or not to authorize casino gambling at or adjacent to the Oaklawn racetrack and at two casino establishments in Hot Springs.
CALIFORNIA
NOVEMBER 5:
--$2 billion Los Angeles Unified School District, Calif., school bonds.
--$995 million, California Proposition 204 - Safe, Clean, Reliable Water Supply Act. Would authorize the issuance of general obligation bonds to finance water programs.
--$750 million Los Angeles, Calif., park bonds.

--$700 million, California Proposition 205 - Youthful and Adult Offender Local Facilities Bond Act of 1996. Would authorize the issuance of general obligation bonds to construct and renovate county juvenile and adult correctional facilities.
--$400 million, Proposition 206 - Veterans' Bond Act of 1996. Would authorize the issuance of general obligation bonds to fund a program of farm, home and mobile home loans.
--$319 million Los Angeles County, Calif., greenbelt, zoo improvement bonds.
--$225 million Sacramento Unified School District, Calif., school GO bonds.
--$100 million San Francisco, Calif., GOs.
--$45 million Sequoia Union High School District, Calif., school GOs.
--$6 Ravenswood City Elementary School District, in Palo Alto, Calif., school GOs.
--Proposition 210 - Minimum Wage Increase. Increases the current state minimum wage of $4.25 per hour to $5.00 per hour on March 1, 1997 and then to $5.75 per hour on March 1, 1998.
--Proposition 217 - Top Income Tax Brackets. Continues highest tax rates of 10 percent and 11 percent on residents with taxable income over $100,000 and $200,000 respectively.

--Proposition 218 - Voter Approval for Local Government Taxes. Limits authority of local governments to impose taxes and property-related assessments, fees and charges. Requires majority of voters approve increases in general taxes and reiterates that two-thirds must approve special taxes.
COLORADO
NOVEMBER 5
--$100 million Colorado Springs, Colo., school bonds.
--Amendment 11 - Eliminates property tax exemption of churches.

--Amendment 16 - Changes Colorado State Board of Land Commissioners' current constitutional duty of maximizing revenue from state trust lands to managing the land to produce reasonable and consistent income over time; permits the state legislature to enact laws that allow the public school fund to be used to invest in and guarantee school district bonds and to make loans to school districts.
--Amendment 18 - Permit certain gambling in Trinidad, Colo.

--Referendum A - Require 60 percent majority vote, instead of simple majority vote, of people to amend state constitution; provides that amendments to the constitution previously adopted with less than 60 percent of the votes may be amended or repealed until January 1, 2003, with simple majority of votes cast.
--Referendun D - Allow unemployment insurance taxes to be increased without voter approval.
CONNECTICUT
NOVEMBER 5

--Cheshire: $1 million for the acquisition of land for recreational, open space, conservation, educational and municipal purposes and the issuance of bonds and notes in the same amount to defray the expenses; $2.9 million be appropriated for building an indoor/outdoor swimming pool and bonds in the same amount.

--Danbury: appropriations aggregating $14.9 million for various public improvements and authorizing the issuance of $14.9 million of bonds to meet such appropriations, and pending issuance, the making of temporary borrowings.
--Derby: appropriate $4.7 million for road and pavement constructions, storm drainage, improvements and bonds and temporary notes.

--East Hartford: $6 million be appropriated and bonds authorized for implementing the Main Street Business District Redevelopment; $2.95 million be appropriated and bonds authorized for roof repairs and paving improvements at various town schools and for an addition to Silver Lane School; $1.8 million be appropriated and bonds authorized for the planning, design and reconstruction of Lord, Drennan Goldstar Town Pools.
--Glastonbury: $5.75 million be appropriated for the Wells-Turner Memorial Library renovations and expansion and authorizing the issuance of bonds and notes in same amount.

--Groton: an ordinance appropriating $10.388 million and authorizing bonds and notes in the same amount for additions and improvements to the Water Pollution Control Facility and a sewer system evaluation study.

--Hartford: an ordinance authorizing $20 million of bonds for improvements to certain schools be approved; 5 ordinances authorizing the issuance of a total of $13.7 million of city bonds for planning, acquisition, construction, reconstruction and renovation of 5 schools throughout the city; an ordinance authorizing $16 million of bonds for renovations and improvements to Hartford public libraries, central library and 3 branches.
--Middletown: bond ordinance and appropriations for $9.96 million for the acquisition of land and for the planning, acquisition and construction of a new police headquarters.
--Montvale: $2.5 million be appropriated and bonds authorized for the expansion and modification of the Montvale Sewage Treatment plant.

--Norwalk: Section 1-289 of the Norwalk charter be amended to provide for the common council to set a cap on the operating budget; Section 1-669 of City of Norwalk existing referendum procedure be amended to allow for a binding referendum on the city's operating budget.

--Norwich: $11.5 million be appropriated and bonds authorized for the expansion and renovation of Samuel Huntington and Bishop elementary schools; $11 million be appropriated and bonds authorized for the implementation of citywide schools system computer technology improvements.
--Plainville: appropriate $2.5 million for the athletic fields project and authorize the issuance of bonds and notes.

--Waterbury: Charter Section 1553 be amended to clarify that the auditing functions are performed by the Department of Audit; Charter Section 2010 be amended so that the investment powers of the board of agents of the Silas Bronson Library are governed by section 45a - 234 of the Connecticut general statutes and the prudent investor rule and to eliminate the mortgage powers of the library board.
--Watertown: appropriate $7.275 million for the Town Hall Campus Complex project and authorize the issuance of bonds or notes in the same amount to finance said appropriation.
--Windsor: $1.3 million appropriation and bond authorization for an addition and renovation to the Poquonock Fire House.
DELAWARE
FLORIDA

--$35 million Fort Lauderdale, Fla., GOs for parks.
--Question No. 1 - Proposal requiring two-thirds voter approval for statewide tax increases.

--Question No 2 -- Would convene the next Constitutional Revision Commission in 1997 instead of 1998 as previously planned, and would give the panel more leeway in recommending changes to the state constitution.
--Question 4 - Impose fee on sugar production in the Everglades.

--Question No. 5 - Provides that those in the Everglades Agricultural Area who cause water pollution within Everglades Protection Area or the Everglades Agricultural Area be primarily responsible for paying the cost of the abatement of that pollution.

--Question No. 6 - Establish an Evergaldes Trust Fund for the purposes of conservation and protection of natural resources and abatement of water pollution, funded through any sources, including gifts and state or federal funds.
--Escambia County, Fla., votes on property tax increase to fund land preservation.
MARCH 25
--Pinellas Cty, Fla., 10-year extension of one-cent sales tax increase for schools.
GEORGIA

--Constitutional Amendment 1 - Referendum on proposal to end intangibles tax.
--Constitutional Amendment 2 - Referendum on proposal allowing school systems to impose one percent sales tax for construction.

--Constitutional Amendment 3 - Allow General Assembly to create "enterprise zones" exempt from taxes levied by state , county, city or any combination thereof to persons, firms or corporations which create job opportunities within designated enterprise zones to provide employment opportunities.
--Referendun A - Exempt from ad valorem taxes certain vans and buses owned by religous groups.
--Referendum B - Exempt from ad valorem taxes certain property owned by historical fraternal groups.
HAWAII
NOVEMBER 5
1 - Allow use of revenue bonds to finance a loan program to make loans to state property insurance programs that provide hurricane insurance coverage to the general public.
2 - Allow state to appropriate funds of the state educational facilities improvement special fund for periods beyond three years to allow for acquisition or construction of public school facilities.

3 - Prevents the lapsing of unencumbered general obligation bond funds which are deemed necessary by the legislature to qualify for federal aid and financing and reimbursement be removed from the provision that requires the lapsing of all unencumbered funds at the end of each fiscal year.
4 - Convene a state constitutional convention.
IDAHO
NOVEMBER 5
Proposition 1 - Limit property taxes to one percent of value subject to asssessment and providing exceptions.

Proposition 3 - Limit authority of state officials to enter into agreements for the receipt and storage of additional radioactive waste in Idaho. Would require any such agreement to be approved by state legislature and voters.
ILLINOIS
NOVEMBER 5

--Voters in 19 Illinois counties will be asked to approve a limit on local property tax increases. Under the measure, annual increases in local property tax collections would be 2capped at five percent or the rate of inflation, whichever is less. The restriction would also prohibit the issuance of general obligation debt without voter approval. Counties slated to hold tax cap elections are: Boone, Champaign, Christian, Franklin, Jackson, Kankakee, Lee, Logan, Macoupin, Massac, Menard, Monroe,Morgan, Randolph, Sangamon, Schuyler, 2Union, Williamson and Winnebago.
--$4.5 million Mokena, Ill., park GOs.
INDIANA

IOWA
KANSAS
KENTUCKY

LOUISIANA

MAINE
NOVEMBER 5
Maine is planning to ask its voters to approve or reject a total of around $40 million of bond initiatives:
--$16.5 million to clean up public health, hazardous substance discharge sites, including tire stockpiles, with $9 million set aside for drinking water grants for cities and towns.
--$11 million to encourage job growth and economic vitality by helping agricultural enterprises and small businesses get capital.
--$10 million to clean up water pollution and drinking water problems.
--$3 million for capital improvements at state parks.
MARYLAND
NOVEMBER 5
--$89.6 million Baltimore County, Md., GOs for schools.

MASSACHUSETTS

--Shall Athol issue bonds to for refurbishing a high scholl that would be exempt?

--Should a Cape Cod Land Bank be established to protect drinking water, buy open space and conservation land, provide bicycling and walking trails, enhance recreation, help first-time home buyers, and be funded by a one-percent fee on all land transfers at the Barnstable county registry of deeds, exempting the first $100,000 of the purchase price?
--Shall Dover issue bonds for a new town garage and site improvements at 2 Dedham Street that would be exempt?
--Shall Easthampton issue bonds to build a new facility for the fire and police department that would be exempt?
--Shall Millbury issue bonds to pay for building sewage system and appurtenant works in the Oak Pond area tha would be exempt?

--Shall Millis issue bonds for drawings, bid documents, project representations, construction contracts and furnishings for major renovations to the Millis Middle School/High School Building that would be exempt?
--Shall Needham issue bonds not to exceed $5.75 miln for extraordinary repairs and additions to the Newman School Building that would be exempt?
MICHIGAN
NOVEMBER 5

--Proposal E - to allow three casinos in Detroit, establish a Michigan Gaming Control Board, and impose an 18 percent state tax on gross gaming revenues, allocating 45 percent of the revenues to the state's school aid fund and 55 percent to Detroit.

--Wayne County, Mich. - Voter approval for one percent hotel/motel tax, two percent car rental tax. Revenues from tax would pay off $80 million of bonds that would be sold to help finance a new $225 million domed stadium for the Detroit Lions football team in downtown Detroit.

--Question 675 -Constitutional amendment that would change the way property is assessed for tax purposes. The measure would limit the percentage of fair cash value at which property may be assessed. The percentage for land would be not more than 13.5 percent, nor less than 11 percent. The percentage for personal property would not be more than 15 percent nor less than 10 percent.

--Question 676 - Constitutional amendment that would limit the fair cash value of real property for property tax purposes. The fair cash value would not increase by more than five percent in any taxable year. The limit would apply only to real property assessed by a county assessor.

--Question 677 - Constitutional amendment that would limit the fair cash value on a homestead for property tax purposes. The homestead must be owned by a person age 65 or older, with a gross household income of $25,000 or less.
